title-group.article-title: Foliar spray of carbon quantum dots alleviated cadmium stress in Dracocephalum Moldavica by altering physiological and biochemical responses

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/01papkj44grid.412831.d0000 0001 1172 3536Department of Plant Eco-physiology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran

abstract.p: Carbon quantum dots (CQDs), characterized by their unique structure and remarkable fluorescence properties, could affect physiological efficiency under heavy metal stress by contributing to metal detoxification and ion homeostasis at the cellular level. Thus, a pot experiment with a factorial arrangement (in three replicates) was laid out to investigate the effects of foliar application of CQDs (0, 2, 4, 6, and 8 mg L−1) under various cadmium levels (0, 25 and 50 mg kg−1) in Dracocephalum moldavica (dragonhead) plants. Foliar application of CQDs with 4 mg L⁻¹ concentration (optimal level) mitigated cadmium stress via an enhancement in vacuolar H+-ATPase activity and nutrient uptake. The CQDs also decreased salicylic acid content, reactive oxygen species generation, lipid peroxidation, and antioxidant enzymes activities, while improved photosynthetic performance, including relative electron transport rate, maximum efficiency of photosystem II (Fv/Fm), Rubisco activity, chlorophyll and flavonoid contents, glucose content, and leaf area. These integrated physiological improvements led to an increase of shoot mass and essential oil yield by approximately 15% and 23% under 25 mg kg⁻¹, and 19% and 31% under 50 mg kg⁻¹ Cd toxicities, respectively. However, foliar treatment of CQDs at concentrations exceeding 4 mg L−1 did not lead to statistically significant improvements in plant performance under toxic conditions. These findings suggest that foliar application in appropriate concentrations can help CQDs’ purposeful and economical application in line with boosting the physiological efficiency and productivity of cadmium-stressed dragonhead plants.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1038/s41598-025-18316-z.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cadmium (Cd) is a highly toxic heavy metal that threatens plant production and human health1. Cadmium effects on the environment are related to industrial activities and chemical fertilizers, which increase its accumulation in crops and subsequent entrance in the food chain2. Cadmium toxicity disrupts various physiological and biochemical processes in plants, resulting in reduced photosynthetic efficiency, nutrient uptake, and growth3. Induced oxidative stress and generated reactive oxygen species (ROS) cause a reduction in chlorophyll content and photosynthetic efficiency under Cd-stress conditions4. Plant metabolism is affected by this oxidative damage, which alters the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites for defense systems5.

One of the strategies explored to mitigate the harmful effects of cadmium stress is using nanoparticles as toxicity reducers6. Quantum dots are classified on the bases of carbon core structure and surface functional groups, including carbon quantum dots (CQDs), graphene quantum dots, and carbonized polymer dots7. Based on advancements in nanotechnology, carbon quantum dots have emerged as a promising approach for enhancing plant resistance to abiotic stresses. These nanoscale materials possess unique optical and electrical properties that make them suitable for agricultural applications8,9. CQDs act as electron donors or acceptors, improving the photosynthetic process and light-harvesting efficiency10. Previous studies demonstrated that CQDs can enhance chlorophyll content, which is essential for absorbing light energy and increasing the photosynthetic efficiency in plants7,11. Furthermore, these nanomaterials facilitate electron transport in photosystems, leading to improved carbon fixation12. Their role in mitigating oxidative stress through enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity is also remarkable for improving photosynthetic efficiency under stressful conditions9,13. In soybean plants exposed to drought stress, foliar application of CQDs alleviated stress-induced damage by enhancing photosynthesis and reducing oxidative stress12. Similarly, in rice seedlings under salt stress, foliar application of CQD improved photosynthetic efficiency, antioxidant enzymes activities, and plant biomass10. Other studies7,14 showed that CQDs can alleviate cadmium toxicity by adjusting gene expression and reducing cadmium content in plant tissues. The reduction in antioxidant enzyme activity and osmolyte production suggests that CQDs effectively mitigate stress conditions and help restore the plant’s physiological balance. Therefore, application of CQDs not only supports plant growth, but also plays a key role in promoting sustainable agriculture by strengthening plant resistance to environmental stress conditions12.

Dracocephalum moldavica is a medicinal plant widely recognized for its essential oil and diverse therapeutic properties. As a member of the Lamiaceae family, D. moldavica is rich in bioactive compounds, which contribute to its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial effects15,16. Cultivating plants that produce essential oil can be an effective strategy for managing soil contamination, while generating economic proceeds. Although plant growth and health can be adversely affected by toxic conditions, the essential oil as harvested product typically does not contain contaminants, making it safer for commercial uses17.

The available reports suggest that carbon quantum dots could be used for improving plant performance, without adequate information about the mechanisms of actions. So, this research examines the mechanistic effects of various doses of CQDs on growth and essential oil production of D.moldavica under cadmium toxicity. The primary hypothesis is to prove the potential of these materials in increasing plant physiological performance under cadmium stress. We search for the mechanistic insights of CQDs, with a probe on changes in ATPase pumps activity, which enhance the accumulation of heavy metals in cell vacuole. Moreover, we evaluate the parameters focusing on the role of CQDs in reducing oxidative markers, photosynthetic performance, metal uptake and hormonal balance in plant tissues. Depending on multiple factors such as plant species, root absorption capacity, metal translocation, and tissue-specific accumulation, enhancing shoot mass provides a larger volume of tissue that can help to increase plant ability in cadmium absorption and storage from contaminated soil. This strategy in medicinal plants, not only helps in environmental remediation, but also allows for the sustainable extraction of high-quality essential oils without heavy metal contamination, offering both ecological and economic benefits.

sec.title: Cadmium content and TF
sec.p: The cadmium toxicity significantly interacted with foliar treatment of CQDs for Cd and TF (Table S1). Cadmium toxicity significantly increased the content of Cd in both roots and shoots of dragonhead, compared to non-toxic conditions (Fig. 1A and B).

caption.p: Changes in content of shoot cadmium (A), root cadmium (B), TF (C), H+-ATPase activity of leaf and root (D, E) of dragonhead plants in response to CQDs foliar application under different levels of cadmium. Data represent the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). Different letters indicate significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05. TF: Cd translocation factor.

sec.p: Foliar application of CQDs resulted in a reduction of cadmium content in plant tissues, especially in shoots. The 4 mg L−1 CQDs reduced the cadmium content of roots and shoots by about 12% and 26% under 25 mg kg−1 Cd toxicity and by about 8% and 21% under 50 mg kg−1, respectively, compared to untreated plants (water spraying). However, the CQD treatments did not affect the cadmium content under non-toxic conditions.

The lowest translocation factor (TF) was recorded for 4 mg L−1 CQDs, but other spraying levels had no significant effect on TF, compared to control plants (Fig. 1C). No significant difference was observed in plants treated with 2, 6 and 8 mg L−1 of CQDs.

sec.title: Vacuolar H+-ATPase activity
sec.p: A significant increase of about 92% and 158% in H+-ATPase activity of dragonhead roots was recorded under 25 and 50 mg kg−1 of Cd toxicities, respectively. Foliar spray of 4 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs caused a significant enhancement in H+-ATPase activity, while 8 mg L−1 CQDs showed no significant difference with water-sprayed plants under Cd stress. In response to 4 mg L−1 CQDs spraying, the H+-ATPase activity increased by about 9% under both cadmium toxicity levels (Fig. 1E).

Foliar application of CQDs in levels of 2, 4, and 6 mg L−1 noticeably decreased H+-ATPase activity of leaf by about 7%, 15%, and 4% under moderate toxicity, and 5%, 10%, 5% under high toxicity, respectively. These pump activities in unstressed plants were not affected by foliar treatments (Fig. 1D).

sec.title: Nutrient content
sec.p: The nutrients (N, K, Mg, Fe, and Zn) in leaf tissue declined with an increase in soil cadmium toxicity (Table 1). Various levels of CQDs led to the improvement in leaf N, K, Mg, Fe, and Zn contents in Cd-stressed plants. In unstressed plants, no significant effect of foliar treatments on nutrient content of plants was observed.

caption.p: The content of some elements (mg g−1 DW) in Dragonhead leaves under different levels of cadmium and CQDs foliar application.

table-wrap-foot.p: Data represents the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). .
Different letters in Each column indicates significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05.

sec.p: The 4 mg L−1 CQDs increased leaf nitrogen content by about 17% and 30% under 25 and 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities. However, no significant difference was observed between other CQDs foliar treatments and control condition (water sprayed plants). At high Cd toxicity (50 mg kg−1), the 4 mg L−1 CQDs increased K content by about 5% in comparison with water-sprayed plants. Foliar spray of 4 mg L−1 resulted in the highest Mg content of leaves under toxic conditions, while the other CQDs treatments (2, 6, and 8 mg L−1) showed statistically similar results compared to water-sprayed control plants. The highest Fe and Zn contents were recorded at 4 mg L−1 CQDs with an increase of about 5% and 6% in comparison with control plants. No significant difference was found between 2 and 6 mg L−1, as well as between 8 mg L−1 CQDs and control treatments (Table 1).

sec.title: H2O2 generation and TBARS rate
sec.p: Dragonhead plants experienced an increase in H2O2 production and TBARS rate under toxic conditions (Table 2). Treating plants with CQDs did not significantly affect ROS generation and lipid peroxidation rate under non-toxic conditions. The 2 and 4 mg L−1 CQDs treatments reduced H2O2 content of dragonhead leaves by about 7% and 21% under 25 mg kg−1 of cadmium toxicity, respectively. There was no significant difference of 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs with plants without CQDs under cadmium stress. The 4 mg L−1 CQDs resulted in a reduction of about 21% and 15% in TBARS under 25 and 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities, while 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs showed no significant difference in comparison to control plants (Table 2).

caption.p: Means of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS), catalase (CAT), superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POX), and flavonoids content in dragonhead leaves under different levels of cadmium and CQDs foliar application.

table-wrap-foot.p: Data represents the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). .
Different letters in each column indicate significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05.

sec.title: Antioxidant enzymes activities
sec.p: The moderate and high levels of Cd stress increased the activity of CAT, SOD, and POX in plant leaves, compared to non-toxic condition. The CAT activity reduced in treated plants by CQDs. Foliar application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs showed the highest reduction in CAT activity under cadmium stress conditions. There was no significant difference in CAT activity of plant leaf tissues in control (water-sprayed) and 8 mg L−1 CQDs under moderate and high cadmium toxicities. Application of 4 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs revealed the highest reduction in SOD activity under cadmium toxicity. No significant difference was observed between control and 8 mg L−1 CQDs under 25 and 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities. The levels of 2, 4, and 6 mg L−1 CQDs in comparison with control (water spraying) reduced the POX activity under moderate toxicity by about 26%, 8%, and 29%, respectively. However, there was no statistically significant difference between 8 mg L−1 CQDs and untreated plants. The 4 mg L−1 treatment showed the greatest decline (30%) in POX activity, compared to control plants under high level of cadmium toxicity (Table 2).

sec.title: Flavonoids
sec.p: The moderate and high cadmium toxicities resulted in a decline of about 15% and 25% in flavonoid content of leaves (respectively), compared to non-toxic conditions (Table 2). Foliar treatment of 2 and 4 mg L−1 CQDs in comparison with control plants, improved flavonoid content by approximately 7% and 20%, under 25 mg kg−1 and 8% and 26% under 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities, respectively. The 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs treatments showed no significant difference in flavonoid content in comparison to the control and 2 mg L−1 CQDs (Table 2).

sec.title: Osmolytes
sec.p: Cadmium toxicity increased osmolytes accumulation (Table 3). Foliar application of CQDs led to a reduction in proline and carbohydrates contents of plant leaves. However, this reduction did not show a significant difference with the control plants under non-toxic and moderate stress conditions. Application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs showed the highest reduction in osmolyte content under high cadmium toxicity, compared to untreated plants (Table 3).

caption.p: Means of some parameters in Dragonhead leaves under different levels of cadmium and CQDs foliar application. .

table-wrap-foot.p: Data represents the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). .
Different letters in each column indicate significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05.
DI: Dimensionless indices, Fv/Fm: Maximum quantum efficiency of photosystem II, RETR: Relative electron transfer rate.

sec.title: Chlorophylls, fv/fm, RETR, and leaf area
sec.p: The moderate and high cadmium toxicities resulted in a reduction chlorophylls a and b, Fv/Fm, RETR and leaf area (Table 3). The CQDs noticeably increased these parameters under toxic conditions. However, CQDs did not alter these leaf parameters of dragonhead plants in non-toxic condition. The highest content of chlorophylls (a and b) under both 25 and 50 mg kg−1 toxicities were achieved by application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs. Foliar application of 8 mg L−1 CQDs have no significant effect on chlorophylls content, compared to control. Foliar application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs enhanced Fv/Fm and RETR values by about 19% and 9% under 25 mg kg−1 and by 18% and 15% under 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities, respectively. There was generally no discernible difference between 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs in elevating of these parameters. Foliar treatment of CQDs at 4 mg L−1 had the highest effect on increasing leaf area of dragonhead plants under toxic conditions. This treatment improved the leaf area under both cadmium toxicity levels by approximately 10% (Table 3).

sec.title: Phytohormones contents
sec.p: Increasing cadmium toxicity levels led to a rise in salicylic acid (SA) content and a decline in indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) in plant leaf tissues. In unstressed plants, foliar application of CQDs had no significant impact on SA and IAA contents. However, under cadmium stress, the SA content was notably influenced by CQD treatment. The 4 mg L⁻¹ CQDs application showed a reduction by about 26% and 17% under 25 and 50 mg kg⁻¹ cadmium toxicities, respectively. This was followed by 2 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs application. In high level of cadmium, there was no significant difference between 8 mg L−1 CQDs and untreated plants (Fig. 2A). All CQDs treatments showed a similar effect on rising IAA content under 25 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicity. Under high cadmium toxicity (50 mg kg−1), application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs led to the highest increment of IAA content by about 9%, compared to non-treated plants. This treatment showed a greater increase of about 7% and 12% in the IAA content of plant leaves, compared to 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs (Fig. 2B).

caption.p: Changes in content of SA (A), IAA (B), glucose (C), and rubisco activity (D) of dragonhead plants in response to CQDs foliar application under different levels of cadmium. Data represent the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). Different letters indicate significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05. SA: salicylic acid, IAA: indole acetic acid.

sec.title: Rubisco activity and glucose content
sec.p: Rubisco as a key enzyme and glucose as an essential product of photosynthesis showed a significant reduction by rising cadmium toxicity. Rubisco activity and glucose content revealed a reduction of approximately 62% and 55% under 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicity, compared to non-toxic condition, respectively (Fig. 2C and D). These parameters were increased by foliar application of CQDs under toxic conditions, with the superiority of 4 mg L−1. Treatments of plants with 2, 4, and 6 mg L−1 CQDs improved glucose content by about 15%, 38% and 15% under moderate toxicity, respectively. Application of 8 mg L−1 CQDs had no significant impact on glucose content, compared to 6 mg L−1 and non- CQDs treatments. Foliar application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs resulted in a greater increase of rubisco activity, compared to 6 and 8 mg L−1 CQDs. There was no significant difference in rubisco activity between 6 and 2 mg L−1 CQDs, while 8 mg L−1 CQDs led to a notable reduction in this enzyme activity, compared to 2 mg L−1 under toxic conditions. Foliar application of 4 mg L−1 CQDs exhibited the greatest enhancement in rubisco activity under 25 and 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicities with 46% and 56% increments in comparison with non-CQDs treatment, respectively.

sec.title: Shoot biomass
sec.p: Plant shoot biomass decreased with increasing cadmium toxicities, which increased by foliar application of CQDs (Fig. 3B). The 4 mg L−1 CQDs treatment showed the highest shoot biomass under moderate and high cadmium toxicities by about 15% and 19% increments in comparison with untreated plants, respectively. Application of 4 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs significantly improved plant biomass in comparison with 8 mg L−1 CQDs under moderate cadmium toxicity. Under 50 mg kg−1 cadmium toxicity, the level of 8 mg L−1 CQDs compared to 4 and 6 mg L−1 significantly reduced shoot biomass by about 14% and 10%, respectively.

caption.p: Changes in the content of essential oil (A and B), shoot dry mass (C), and essential oil yield (D) of dragonhead plants in response to CQDs foliar application under different levels of cadmium. Data represent the average of three replicates ± SE (standard error). Different letters indicate significant differences by Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05.

sec.title: Essential oil production
sec.p: The essential oil percentage of plant aerial (vegetative) parts was affected by cadmium toxicity and foliar treatments (Fig. 3A, B). The results showed that foliar applications, especially 4 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs increased essential oil content. Foliar application of 4 and 6 mg L−1 CQDs increased the essential oil yield of dragonhead plants by approximately 10% and 15% under moderate stress and 31% and 22% under high cadmium toxicity, respectively in comparison with untreated plants (Fig. 3D).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Cadmium toxicity as a major environmental stress negatively affects plant physiology, metabolism, and performance18. The high value of cadmium content in plant shoot, cadmium translocation factor and H+-ATPase pump activity (Fig. 1) confirming the increment of cadmium uptake by the plants. Cadmium toxicity disrupted various physiological and biochemical processes, including nutrient uptake (Table 1), antioxidant defense mechanisms (Table 2), and photosynthetic efficiency. Cadmium substitutes for essential cofactors like Mg²⁺ in chlorophyll, disrupts chloroplast structure, and inhibits photosystem II activity, as indicated by reduced chlorophyll content, Fv/Fm ratio, and RETR (Table 3). Moreover, oxidative stress induced by Cd led to excess generation of reactive oxygen species and lipid peroxidation (Table 2). One of the other major biochemical disruptions caused by cadmium toxicity was the reduction in rubisco enzyme activity and glucose content (Fig. 2), both of which are essential for maintaining photosynthetic efficiency and energy metabolism19. Cadmium stress adversely affects carbon fixation by inhibiting rubisco activity as the common target of heavy metals, which limits glucose production and energy availability for plant production and stress tolerance20. Ultimately, these physiological disturbances resulted in a marked reduction in plant shoot biomass and essential oil yield (Fig. 3). Similar disruptions have been reported for Cd-exposed Mentha and Salvia officinalis plants3,21,22.

The results demonstrated that carbon quantum dots potentially alleviated Cd-induced stress through improving physiological performance of plants. Increased activity of vacuolar ATPase in root and decreased H+-ATPase pump activity in leaf (Fig. 1) can be one of the main reasons for the reduced cadmium translocation factor (TF) and the inhibition of heavy metal transportation to aerial organs. These pumps play a crucial role in regulating the distribution of ions and metals within plant cells4. Vacuolar ATPase pumps protons into the vacuole, creating an electrochemical gradient that helps Cd transportation into the vacuole. By sequestering Cd into the vacuoles, the vacuolar ATPase effectively reduces the amount of free Cd in the cytoplasm of root cells. This reduces the amount of available Cd for transport to the shoots via the xylem and consequently decreasing the TF23,24. It was suggested that CQDs by influencing the plant’s internal regulatory mechanisms and enhancing the expression of vacuolar H⁺-ATPase genes accumulate cadmium in the roots and prevent its transport to aboveground parts, which reduces shoot Cd content and oxidative stress12,24.

Foliar application of CQDs, especially at 4 and 6 mg L⁻¹ enhanced photosynthetic performance by boosting chlorophyll content, relative photosynthetic electron transport rate (RETR), and the maximum efficiency of photosystem II (Fv/Fm) (Table 3). These improvements indicate a more effective utilization of light energy, as was observed in previous studies10,11. Due to their unique optical properties, the CQDs can absorb a wide range of light wavelengths and re-emit energy as fluorescence, thereby enhancing photon availability for photosynthesis25. As light-harvesting nanomaterials, CQDs efficiently absorb UV and blue light and emit in the visible range. The chlorophyll pigments can utilize this energy for improved photosynthetic efficiency7,26. This property is more beneficial under stress conditions, in which a decline in chlorophyll content limits the plant’s capacity to absorb adequate light energy18. Application of CQDs can enhance light absorption efficiency in photosystems, leading to more effective electron transport (Table 3) and improved carbon fixation rates11. Improving the chemical efficiency of photosystem II (Table 3) in response to CQDs can be related to the high induction of electron transfer by CQDs12. Improved nutrient availability can also contribute to maintaining the photosynthesis efficiency under stress conditions3,27. Foliar spraying of CQDs enhanced nutrient uptake (Table 1), which is essential for various physiological functions and plant production. The CQDs facilitate ion transport and nutrient availability, potentially by affecting root function and ion channels activity7. Nitrogen and magnesium as the fundamental component of chlorophyll structure directly help the light absorption and energy transformation in photosystems influencing carbon fixation and photosynthetic capacity28.

In response to osmotic stress, plants tend to preserve cellular homeostasis12. Cd toxicity led to a significant increase in proline and soluble carbohydrates, whereas foliar-applied CQDs reduced osmolyte production (Table 3). This indicated that CQDs reduced the need for excessive osmolyte levels by reducing water deficit stress. CQDs could modify the function of aquaporins (water channel proteins in cell membranes), improving water uptake and retention under stress conditions. The antioxidant properties of CQDs help mitigation of ROS-induced membrane damage, thereby preserving membrane integrity and maintaining efficient water transport29. Moreover, improved photosynthetic performance by CQDs treatment can reduce the plant’s dependence on osmolyte overproduction and the excessive diversion of sugars toward osmolyte synthesis under cadmium stress. Under cadmium stress, plants often alter carbohydrate metabolism towards osmolyte production to reduce stress effects7,10.

Foliar application of CQDs significantly reduced H₂O₂ generation, lipid peroxidation (TBARS) level and antioxidant enzymes activity (SOD, CAT, POX) (Table 2). The CQDs chelate with cadmium ions (Cd²⁺) through their functional groups, including carboxyl (-COOH), hydroxyl (-OH), and amino (-NH₂) groups, forming stable complexes that restrict cadmium uptake by plant cells.30 Reducing the cadmium accumulation in plant tissues including roots and shoots (Fig. 1), can alleviate oxidative stress in plants under cadmium toxicity. Application of CQDs improved photosynthetic efficiency, which can be reached by increasing the activity of key photosynthetic enzymes (Fig. 2 D), chlorophyll content and leaf area (Table 3)13. It can mitigate oxidative stress and preserve cellular integrity. Reducing stress impact decreases the plant’s dependence on defense mechanisms such as antioxidant enzymes activities (Table 2)12. By lowering intracellular Cd concentrations, the CQDs limit the ROS generation, allowing plants to downregulate their antioxidant enzyme systems and allocate more energy for growth24.

Phytohormones regulate specific signaling pathways and protect plant cells. It makes them crucial in the regulation of various processes and increasing tolerance to stress31. Treatment with CQDs decreased the content of SA, which protects plants from toxic conditions, but increased IAA as an important growth promoter (Fig. 2). The reduction in SA levels minimizes the need for excessive defense activation. The elevation in IAA levels, driven by improved plant nutrition, facilitated cell division and expansion, leading to overall plant growth enhancement32. As a direct result of hormonal balance and photosynthetic efficiency, the CQDs contributed to leaf area expansion and biomass production (Fig. 3). Increased IAA levels can promote plant leaf area by stimulating cell division and elongation4,32. In CQDs-treated plants, the larger leaf area helps to improve photosynthetic performance by facilitating light absorption12.

Another important consequence of Cd stress was the limitation of rubisco enzyme activity and glucose synthesis (Fig. 2), which are essential for photosynthetic efficiency and plant productivity. Cadmium toxicity negatively impacted carbon fixation by inhibiting rubisco activity, resulting in a reduction of glucose synthesis and energy availability for stress adaptation and plant growth19. Since glucose acts as a source of energy and as a signaling molecule regulates metabolic pathways, its deficiency leads to biomass loss33. Foliar application of CQDs boosted rubisco activity and glucose content, indicating enhanced carbon assimilation. As Rubisco activity controls the rate of photosynthetic carbon assimilation, it directly affects plant biomass production. Application of CQDs improves light absorption, electron transport, and CO₂ fixation efficiency, which can increase glucose synthesis11, that provides energy for excessive dry mass production. The higher dry mass in CQDs-applied plants can be also attributed to the effects of enhanced nutrient uptake, reduced oxidative stress, and improved metabolic stability6,13.

Essential oil synthesis increased as a metabolic demand for protective compounds to counter stress-related damages under cadmium stress, especially under moderate toxicity (25 mg kg−1 soil). Under high toxicity (50 mg kg−1 soil), plant may not be able to efficiently utilize its energy and resources for essential oil production. Prioritizing survival over secondary metabolite production leads to a decrease in essential oil synthesis34. Enhanced light absorption by CQDs can help ATP and NADPH production in photosynthesis, leading to increased carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle. Accordingly, the availability of primary metabolites (sugars and organic acids), which serve as precursors for the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites, including essential oils, will be improved35. Reducing cadmium accumulation, improving stress tolerance, and enhancing nutrients availability can improve the essential oil yield of plants, following an increase in plant dry mass under toxic conditions (Fig. 3). Foliar treatment of 4 mg L⁻¹ was generally the best treatment in improving shoot biomass and essential oil yield under stressful conditions, compared to the other levels. These findings underscore the importance of optimizing CQD dosage to maximize stress-mitigating benefits without compromising cellular homeostasis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study highlights the potential of CQDs foliar spraying as a novel strategy to support physiological efficiency and productivity in Cd-stressed plants. The results demonstrated CQD spraying efficacy in mitigating cadmium toxicity in D. moldavica by first enhancing H⁺-ATPase pump activity in the roots, leading to increased cadmium accumulation in roots and decreased cadmium transfer to the shoots. The reduction of cadmium entry into aerial organs improved nutrient uptake, hormonal balance, photochemical efficiency of photosystem II (Fv/Fm) and relative electron transport rate (RETR). The optimization of photosynthetic processes, combined with improved nutrient uptake, significantly boosted rubisco activity and glucose synthesis, leading to enhanced carbon fixation and leaf expansion. These improvements ultimately resulted in enhanced shoot biomass and essential oil production. Foliar application of 4 mg L⁻¹ CQDs was found to be the most effective concentration for improving resilience and production in Cd-stressed dragonhead plants. Higher concentrations (6 and 8 mg L⁻¹) did not show tangible benefits. However, further research is required to assess the effects of CQD application across different plant species and environmental conditions.

sec.title: Experimental conditions
sec.p: The soil texture was silty loam with 17.8 cmol kg−1 cation exchange capacity (CEC), 1.3% organic matter (OM), 1.6 dS m−1 electrical conductivity (EC), 6.3 pH, 0.08% nitrogen, 22 mg kg−1 available phosphorus, 148 mg kg−1 available potassium, and 0.11 mg kg−1 Cd content before contamination. The soil pH, EC, and potassium content were determined by saturated soil extracts36, while organic matter was quantified through dichromate oxidation according to Schulz37. The content of available phosphorus was assessed by sodium bicarbonate extraction38.

Experimental soil was contaminated with cadmium according to the method described by Rahimzadeh and Ghassemi-Golezani39. Different cadmium sulfate (CdSO4) concentrations (25 and 50 mg kg−1 soil as moderate and high toxicity, respectively) were incorporated into the experimental soil in pots (20 × 20 cm, with a soil capacity of 3 kg). The selective cadmium doses were identified through preliminary testing based on the response of Dracocephalum moldavica to various cadmium levels (Table S2). After mixing, the contaminated soils were incubated at about 22°C for 14 days, with the moisture level kept at field capacity (FC). The cadmium content was measured in random soil samples taken after the incubation period. Dragonhead seeds (Tabriz ecotype) were purchased from a local market. The sterilized seeds were sown in 0.5 cm depth of the pots, and irrigated with tap water to achieve 100% FC. The established seedlings were thinned to a maximum of 5 plants per pot. The carbon quantum dots (CQDs) were purchased from Nanoshel Company of India, with a purity of 99.99% and an average particle size (APS) of < 10 nm. Thirty days after sowing (DAS), plants were well sprayed with different levels of CQDs (2, 4, 6, and 8 mg L−1). The control plants were sprayed with distilled water to compare with CQDs-treated plants. A hand-held sprayer with a flow rate of 1.5 L per minute was used for the foliar application. Approximately 50 mL of solution was applied per pot, using a handheld sprayer equipped with a nozzle generating droplets with an average diameter of 100 μm. The average volume applied per plant was about 10 mL. This volume was selected based on preliminary trials to ensure complete and uniform coverage of leaf surfaces without excessive runoff. Factors such as spray angle, distance, speed and time of spraying were respected. The pots were kept in controlled greenhouse conditions (Fig. S1), with a photoperiod of about 13 h and the day and night mean temperatures of 25°C and 18°C, respectively. Finally, 80 days after sowing, the plants were harvested to evaluate various physiological and biochemical parameters.

sec.title: Cadmium content in plant tissues
Vacuolar H+-ATPase activity
sec.p: To evaluate H⁺-ATPase activity, 15 µg of each tonoplast sample (isolated according to the method outlined by Queiros et al.40 was added to a reaction mixture composed of 30 mM Hepes-Tris, 3 mM MgSO₄, 0.5 mM NaN₃, 0.1 mM Na₃VO₄, 5 mM KCl, 0.1 mM Na₂MoO₄, and 3 mM ATP. The reaction was then completed by the addition of 50 µL of trichloroacetic acid and incubated for 20 min at 37 °C. Subsequently, the absorbance of the samples was tested at 820 nm using a Dynamica Halo DB 20 UV-Visible Spectrophotometer (UK).

sec.title: Nutrient content in leaves
sec.p: The nitrogen content in leaves was analyzed using the Kjeldahl method. The content of potassium, magnesium, iron, and zinc were assessed in leaves dried at 550 °C for 7 h. The samples were digested with 5 M HNO3, and then distilled water was added up to a final volume of 50 mL. The nutrients were then measured by atomic absorption spectrophotometry and reported as mg g−1 DW (dry weight)41.

sec.title: ROS generation
sec.p: The level of H2O2 was quantified using 0.1 g of leaf tissue, which was homogenized with 2 mL of a 0.1% trichloroacetic acid at 4 °C. The homogenate was centrifuged for 10 min at 12,000 g. Then, 0.5 mL of the supernatant was combined with 0.5 mL of potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) and 1 mL of potassium iodide (1 M). The absorbance of the samples was recorded spectrophotometrically at 390 nm42.

sec.title: Lipid peroxidation rate
sec.p: Fresh leaf tissue (0.1 g) was homogenized in 2 mL of 0.1% trichloroacetic acid and centrifuged at 12,000 g for 10 min. Then, 0.5 mL of the supernatant was combined with 2 mL of a 0.5% thiobarbituric acid (TBA) solution, which was prepared by dissolving 0.5 g of TBA in 100 mL of distilled water. The resulting mixture was incubated at 100 °C for 10 min. The reaction was then terminated by placing the mixture in an ice bath. The absorbance of the sample was measured at 532 and 600 nm to quantify the formation of the malondialdehyde (MDA)-TBA complex, which is an indicator of lipid peroxidation rate43.

sec.title: Antioxidant enzyme activities
sec.p: The protein of leaf samples was extracted following the Bradford method44. The Bovine serum albumin (BSA) was used as protein standard. A frozen leaf sample (0.5 g) was ground in liquid nitrogen and homogenized in 4 mL of potassium phosphate buffer. Then, homogenate was centrifuged at 15,000 g for 15 min, and the supernatant was used for enzyme activity assays.

An enzyme extract (0.1 mL) was combined with a reaction mixture containing guaiacol (10 mM), potassium phosphate buffer (50 mM, pH 7.0), and H2O2 (30 mM). The variation in absorbance was recorded at 470 nm for 2 min to estimate peroxidase (POX) activity45. The catalase (CAT) activity was assessed using the method by Maehly and Chance46, which involved quantifying the rate of hydrogen peroxide degradation by the reduction of absorbance at 240 nm. The reaction mixture contained phosphate buffer (50 mM L−1, pH 7.0), hydrogen peroxide (30 mM L−1), and 50 µL of the enzyme extract. The activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD) was measured by the enzyme’s capacity to impede the photochemical reduction of nitro-blue tetrazolium. The reaction mixture consists of phosphate buffer (50 mM, pH 7.8), riboflavin (2 µM), methionine (13 mM), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA, 0.1 mM), and nitro-blue tetrazolium (75 µM), which acts as the substrate reacting with superoxide anions. The absorbance was measured at 560 nm, using a spectrophotometer47.

sec.title: Osmolytes
sec.p: For proline assessment, 50 mg of leaf samples were homogenized in sulfosalicylic acid, followed by the addition of an equal volume of ninhydrin solution and glacial acetic acid. The mixture was heated for 1 h at 100 °C, followed by addition of 4 mL of toluene. The absorbance was recorded at 520 nm using a spectrophotometer48. The soluble carbohydrates in plant tissues were determined using the phenol-sulfuric acid method as described by Dubois et al.49. Fresh leaf samples were homogenized in ethanol and then filtered. Next, samples were combined with 5% phenol and 98% sulfuric acid, and the absorbance was read at 485 nm.

sec.title: Chlorophyll and flavonoids
sec.p: The Arnon50 method was applied to estimate the content of chlorophyll a and b. After homogenizing 0.5 g of frozen leaf tissues in 4 ml of 80% acetone, the samples were centrifuged at 12,000 g for 20 min at 4 °C. The absorbance of the supernatant was measured using a spectrophotometer at 645 and 663 nm. The Zhishen et al.51 method was used to calculate the total flavonoid in plant leaves.

sec.title: Leaf area, fv/fm, and RETR
sec.p: The leaf area (LA) was measured by a leaf area meter (model ADCAM 300-United Kingdom). A portable chlorophyll fluorometer (OS-30, Opti-Sciences, USA) was used to measure chlorophyll fluorescence in leaves. This technique assesses the photochemical efficiency of photosystem II (Fv/Fm), by measuring the emitted light (fluorescence) from chlorophyll molecules after excitation with a specific light pulse, as well as the relative photosynthetic electron transport rate (RETR). It utilizes a pulse-modulated light source and a detector to measure the fluorescence emitted by the leaf. The Fv/Fm (variable fluorescence/maximum fluorescence) was estimated by measuring minimum fluorescence (Fo) and maximum fluorescence (Fm) of dark-adapted leaves. The Fv/Fm representing the maximum photochemical quantum yield of photosystem II (PSII), which was calculated as (Fm - Fo)/Fm. The measurements were taken from leaves that were dark-adapted for 30 min, using leaf clips prior to measurement52.

sec.title: Phytohormones
sec.p: The content of salicylic acid (SA) and indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) in plant leaves were measured, using the ELISA kits specific to each hormone. Fresh leaf samples (0.1 g) were ground in liquid nitrogen and extracted with 1 mL of cold 80% methanol containing 1 mM butylated hydroxyl toluene (BHT) as an antioxidant to prevent degradation of hormones. The mixture was vortexed and incubated on ice for 30 min. After centrifugation at 12,000 g for 15 min at 4 °C, the supernatant was collected and used for hormonal analysis. Following the ELISA method, standards and samples were added in duplicate to a 96-well microtiter plate pre-coated with specific antibodies against SA and IAA. After incubation at 37 °C for 30 min, the wells were washed thoroughly with wash buffer. The TMB (tetramethylbenzidine) as chromogenic substrate was added, and then the reaction was stopped by 2 M sulfuric acid. The absorbance was then recorded at 450 nm using an ELISA reader53.

sec.title: Rubisco activity
sec.p: where A0 and A1 are the initial and equilibrium absorption values, respectively, V is the total volume of reaction solution, ϵ is the extinction coefficient of NADH (6.22 mM−1cm−1), d is the thickness of cuvette (1 cm), Δt is the reaction time, and v is the enzyme solution volume. This method reflecting the enzyme’s capacity to CO₂ fixation in plant tissues.

sec.title: Glucose content
sec.p: To measure glucose as the final product of photosynthesis, leaf samples were powdered in liquid nitrogen and then homogenized in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (PBS). The homogenate was centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 g. The glucose content was determined using the glucose oxidase-peroxidase (GOD-POD) assay. The reaction mixture consisted of glucose oxidase, peroxidase, 4-aminoantipyrine, and 0.1 mM hydrogen peroxide, which was added to 0.1 M PBS (pH 7.0). For the assay of glucose, 100 µL of the leaf extract (supernatant) was added to 1 mL of the reaction mixture. This mixture was incubated at 25 °C for 30 min, and then the absorbance was read at 450 nm, using a spectrophotometer56.

sec.title: Plant performance and essential oil extraction
sec.p: Two random plant were removed from each pot and shoot dry weight (DW) was determined after oven-drying at 80 °C for 48 h. Two other plants were harvested from each pot and dried at room temperature of about 25 °C for one week in a shade condition with adequate airflow. The essential oil of air-dried plants was extracted using a Clevenger apparatus by hydrodistillation for 3 h. The extracted samples were dehydrated with anhydrous sodium sulfate. Essential oil yield (mg per plant) was calculated as: shoot mass × essential oil percentage16.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: In the first step, the normality of data distribution was checked by Anderson-Darling test and in the next step, the data were analyzed by Minitab Statistical Software, Version 20.4 (Minitab LLC, State College, PA, USA, available at: https://www.minitab.com/en-us and https://www.minitab.com/en-us/support/minitab/minitab-software-updates/) following the experimental design. Significant differences among means of each parameter were tested by the Tukey HSD test at p ≤ 0.05. Given the large differences in cadmium content in D. moldavica tissues (root and shoot) under control and stressful conditions, the statistical analysis of these traits was performed separately in each cadmium treatment level.

sec.p: Below is the link to the electronic supplementary material.

ack.p: We appreciate the University of Tabriz for the support of this research.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: K.G.G. designed and supervised the experiment and also edited the manuscript, and S.R. implemented the experiment and carried out the initial writing.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The data are presented within the manuscript as tables and figures.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Statement of compliance
notes.p: This experimental research on plants complies with relevant institutional, national, and international guidelines and legislation.
